item.title: Final Fantasy 7 Re-Release Launches to ‘Mostly Negative’ Reviews on Steam
item.content:encoded:
The original Final Fantasy 7 has re-released on Steam, and it doesn’t seem to be faring well with players due to some issues, as reviews have dropped to ‘Mostly Negative.’

For those unaware, Square Enix announced last month that Final Fantasy 7 will be re-released on Steam, replacing the 2013 version. Today, the new version has arrived with some brand-new features; however, these seem to be causing many gameplay issues, which are hampering the experience at launch.

Original Final Fantasy 7 Re-Release on Steam Seemingly Riddled with Issues

To understand the problem, players will first have to know the new features that have arrived with the original Final Fantasy 7’s re-release on Steam. Players have received a 3x Speed mode, which allows them to battle, travel, and participate in select events at three times the speed. There’s also an option to turn off random battle encounters, a Battle Enhancement mode that allows players to recover HP/MP during battles, max out the Limit gauge, and an Autosave feature.

Spotted by GamesRadar+, the majority of complaints seem to be with the game’s new speed-up feature, with players highlighting issues like “combat speed is completely broken”, “the FPS limit has been increased from 15 to 30, doubling the speed of fights and actions but without adapting the animations so the actions desyncs with the audio,” and more. Some others have mentioned issues with overlays, textures, and screen tearing.

However, some reviewers have pointed out that Square Enix was prompt in releasing a patch the same day to fix the combat speed issue. But will this be enough to get the review rating back up?

In other news, Final Fantasy 7 Remake Intergrade on the Switch 2 is not a PS4 port. Additionally, the multiplatform release will not compromise the graphics in FF7 Remake Part 3. item.title: Xbox CEO Says Brand Won’t Shift Focus to Chase Trends
item.content:encoded:
Xbox CEO Asha Sharma discusses the brand’s efforts to retain user engagement and grow its player base in an increasingly competitive landscape.

In 2026, there are so many entities fighting for engagement. Social media apps like YouTube and TikTok are competing with streamers like Netflix and Prime Video, as well as video game platforms like PlayStation and Xbox.

As Xbox looks to reshape its future following the retirement of Phil Spencer and the appointment of Asha Sharma as new CEO, the organization is recommitting to players rather than chasing emerging trends.

Asha Sharma Doesn’t Want Xbox’s Developers to Lose Focus

In an interview with Windows Central’s Jez Corden, Sharma was asked about her plans to explore new avenues to help Xbox grow its audience. In response, she reaffirmed her commitment to loyal users, saying that if the time comes to invest in a different community, they will evaluate these things on an individual basis.

What I don’t want to do is have any creator at Xbox dilute their focus to chase an emerging community,” Sharma explained. “If we want to invest in a new community, we’ll look at how to do that. But it’s really important that people stay true to their core when they’re building.”

Elsewhere in the interview, she discussed her plans to drive Xbox’s rise through hardware and first-party offerings. Read her full comments here. Learn more about Phil Spencer’s retirement here.

item.title: Can You Preload Marathon Server Slam Playtest?
item.content:encoded:
Marathon is Bungie’s foray into the extraction shooter scene, with the Destiny veterans taking their slick first-person gunplay and applying it to the tried and tested formula. If you’re curious about the project and can’t wait until launch to try it, then Bungie has just the thing for you…

The Marathon Server Slam Playtest. In the weekend leading up to the official launch, Bungie are hosting a free-to-play event for anyone to join and give Marathon a shot. It’s a great chance for Bungie to stress-test its servers, whilst the fanbase can decide whether they want to buy into the long-term future of the franchise.

If you’re eager to get involved, Bungie have officially announced whether you can preload the Marathon Server Slam Playtest, and all of the details can be found down below.

Can You Preload The Marathon Server Slam Playtest

Sadly, you will not be able to preload the Marathon Server Slam Playtest, so you’ll have to hit download the second it launches on February 26.

This news was confirmed in the official Marathon Discord, and it’s disappointed a lot of the player base who wanted to dive right in the second it goes live. However, there was a silver lining, as in the same message, it was confirmed that you will be able to preload Marathon for the full release.

  • More Insider Gaming: Every Runner Shell In Marathon

So, for those dying to return to Tau Ceti after the Server Slam Playtest, fear not, as once Marathon goes live on March 5, you’ll have the option to have it downloaded and ready for launch.

How To Take Part In The Marathon Server Slam Playtest

To get involved in the Marathon Server Slam Playtest, all you need to do is download it for free once it releases on whichever platform you intend to play it on.

Unlike some other beta-adjacent playtests, you don’t need to have signed up for the Server Slam Playtest, nor do you need to have pre-ordered a version of the game. Simply download the Playtest when it becomes available, and you can hop right into the world of Marathon.

  • More Insider Gaming: Bungie Outlines Plans To Counter Cheaters In Marathon

Based on the information made available by Bungie, there will be plenty of content to sink your teeth into. If you’re looking for an in-depth explanation, ranging from the available content to the exact time the Server Slam Playtest launches, Insider Gaming has just the article you’re looking for, linked right here.

Will you be taking part in the Marathon Server Slam Playtest? Share your thoughts and search for fellow Runners in the official Insider Gaming Discord Server.

item.title: All Marathon Server Slam Test Start Times Confirmed
item.content:encoded:
Bungie is releasing one final gameplay outing for its new shooter before release day: The Marathon Server Slam Test. Its start times are crucial if you want to get into the action straightaway, and this guide has everything you need to know.

Marathon‘s reputation has gotten stronger as time has gone on. Bungie has clearly listened to any feedback and criticisms, taken them on board, and the final result should be very promising: Could it rival ARC Raiders?

It remains to be seen, but you can see for yourself the state of the FPS via the Marathon Server Slam Test.

What Time Does Marathon Server Slam Test Start?

The Marathon Server Slam Test starts at 10 AM PT and gradually rolls out in other regions, with some of you getting to play in the middle of the night and even the crack of dawn.

  • More Insider Gaming: Every Runner Shell In Marathon—All Abilities, Explained

Anyone on Pacific Time gets the usual honor of going first where official start times are concerned. Whereas residents of Australia and New Zealand technically don’t get to play the Server Slam Playtest until the day after!

Check out all the key time zones and regions below.

How Long Is The Marathon Server Slam Test?

Including its start date, you basically get four days to play the Marathon Server Slam Playtest, as it ends on March 2 at 10 AM PT.

  • More Insider Gaming: Does Marathon Have Crossplay?

You get a bit longer than the weekend to play Marathon, so soak up the shooter, and accumulate as many hours as you can to help support the game, find bugs, and ensure Bungie’s new IP has the best chance of success at launch.
